qas.question: Besides Aves, what group contains the only living representatives of the reptile clade Archosauria?
Who defined Aves to include only the crown group of the set of modern birds?
What is a sister group to Aves?

context: Aves and a sister group, the <a0_0><a2_0>clade Crocodilia<a2_0/><a0_0/>, contain the only living representatives of the reptile clade Archosauria. During the late 1990s, Aves was most commonly defined phylogenetically as all descendants of the most recent common ancestor of modern birds and Archaeopteryx lithographica. However, an earlier definition proposed by Jacques Gauthier gained wide currency in the 21st century, and is used by many scientists including adherents of the Phylocode system. <a1_0>Gauthier<a1_0/> defined Aves to include only the crown group of the set of modern birds. This was done by excluding most groups known only from fossils, and assigning them, instead, to the Avialae, in part to avoid the uncertainties about the placement of Archaeopteryx in relation to animals traditionally thought of as theropod dinosaurs.
